[[File:Hillary Clinton at the United Nations Conference on Women in Beijing, China.jpg|thumb|alt=The First Lady Hillary Clinton during her speech in Beijing, China.|First Lady of the United States [[Hillary Clinton|Hillary Rodham Clinton]] during her speech in Beijing, China.]]
"'''Women's rights are human rights'''" is a phrase used in the [[feminism|feminist movement]]. The phrase was first used in the 1980s and early 1990s. Its most prominent usage is as the name of a speech given by [[Hillary Clinton|Hillary Rodham Clinton]], the [[First Lady of the United States]], on 5 September 1995, at the [[United Nations]] [[Fourth World Conference on Women]] in [[Beijing]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Fester|first=Gertrude|title=Women's Rights Are Human Rights|journal=Agenda: Empowering Women for Gender Equity |date=1994|volume=20|pages=76–79|jstor=4065874}}</ref> In this speech she sought to closely link the notion of [[women's rights]] with that of [[human rights]]. In the speech, Clinton used the phrase within the longer, bidirectional refrain, "human rights are women's rights and women's rights are human rights."
==First uses== The notion that "women's rights are human rights" was first expressed with different phrasing by the abolitionists and proto-feminists [[Sarah Moore Grimké]] and [[Angelina Grimké|Angelina Grimké Weld]] in the late 1830s. In her series of ''Letters on the Equality of the Sexes'', Sarah Moore Grimké writes, "Consequently I know nothing of man’s rights, or woman’s rights; human rights are all that I recognize".<ref>''Letters on the Equality of the Sexes, and the Condition of Woman''. Addressed to Mary S. Parker. Boston: Isaac Knapp, 1838. Reprinted by Forgotten Books, 2012.</ref> A similar expression is used by her sister, Angelina Grimké Weld, in her speeches and personal letters. In a letter to her friend Jane Smith, she writes, "whatever is morally right for a man to do is morally right for a woman to do. I recognized no rights but human rights."<ref>The Grimke Sisters, ''Sarah and Angelina Grimke: the First American Women Advocates of Abolition and Woman's Rights''. Washington, DC, Lee and Shepard, 1885. Reprint by Greenwood Press, 1969. Reprint by Hard Press, 2014, p.109.</ref>
The phrase "Women's rights are human rights" was used intermittently during the 1980s and first half of the 1990s, before Clinton's speech. Instances include in 1984, when ''[[The New York Times]]'' quoted the head of [[New York City Human Rights Law|New York City's Human Rights Commission]], Marcella Maxwell, using this phrase in conversation.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/01/style/a-fighter-for-roghts.html | title=A Fighter for Rights | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=June 1, 1984|author=Lawson, Carol}}</ref> It was again used in 1985 by [[Cecilia Medina]], a noted Chilean jurist, in a seminal paper on feminism.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3Eg51ozCTCUC&pg=PA63&dq=%22women's%20rights%20are%20human%20rights%22#v=onepage&q=%22women's%20rights%20are%20human%20rights%22&f=false|title=Women, Feminist Identity, and Society in the 1980s: Selected Papers|first1=Myriam|last1=Díaz-Diocaretz|first2=Iris M.|last2=Zavala|date=1 January 1985|publisher=John Benjamins Publishing|via=Google Books}}</ref> The title of her work was 'Women's Rights as Human Rights: Latin American Countries and the Organization of American States (OAS).' In articulating the historic idea, Medina wrote, "As a logical consequence of the fact that women's rights are human rights, feminism, in theory, is a movement to achieve a democratic society, without which human rights may not be fully enjoyed."
Canadian politician [[Ed Broadbent]], who was the head of the [[International Centre for Human Rights and Democratic Development]], used the phrase in an interview with the ''[[Calgary Herald]]'' in January 1993 when he stated, "If we believe as a society that women's rights are human rights, then it is time to stop discriminating against women in refugee policy."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://publications.gc.ca/Collection-R/LoPBdP/BP/bp370-e.htm#(2) | title=Gender-related Refugee Claims | publisher=Government of Canada Publications | date=March 1994}}</ref> The phrase was used by Laurel Fletcher during a 1993 international law symposium called ''Human Rights Violations Against Women'', an edited version of which was published by Fletcher, Allyn Taylor and Joan Fitzpatrick in 1994.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://scholarship.law.berkeley.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1216&context=facpubs|title=Human Rights Violations Against Women|first1=Laurel|last1=Fletcher|first2=Allyn|last2=Taylor|first3=Joan|last3=Fitzpatrick|journal=Whittier Law Review|volume=15|issue=319|year=1994|access-date=2017-01-21}}</ref> Article 3 of Malaysian Charter on Human Rights, published in December 1994 by a number of non-governmental organizations, begins with the sentence "Women's Rights are Human Rights."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurights.or.jp/archives/other_documents/section1/1994/03/malaysian-charter-on-human-rights-1994.html|title=Malaysian Charter on Human Rights|publisher=Malaysian NGOs|year=1994|accessdate=2017-01-21}}</ref>
== Clinton's speech == [[File:Women's rights are human rights.ogg|thumb|right|Audio file of Clinton declaring, "If there is one message that echoes forth from this conference, let it be that human rights are women's rights and women's rights are human rights, once and for all."]] [[File:First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton's Remarks to the Fourth Women's Conference in Beijing, China.webm|thumb|right|Footage of Clinton's speech in its entirety. At approximately the 14:45 mark, Clinton utters the famous line, "Women's rights are human rights"]] {{commons category|Hillary Rodham Clinton delivering Women's Right Are Human Rights speech}}
In planning to make her speech, the 47-year-old Clinton defied both internal administration pressure and external Chinese pressure to soften her remarks.<ref name="nw-doctrine" /><ref name="nyt122607">{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/26/us/politics/26clinton.html |title=The Résumé Factor: Those 8 Years as First Lady |last=Healy | first= Patrick |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 26, 2007}}</ref> The [[U.S. State Department]] and the [[National Security Agency]] both tried to dissuade her on the grounds that it would irritate the Chinese.<ref name=timesfd/> While President [[Bill Clinton]] had seen the speech in advance, his aides had not, and White House Chief of Staff [[Thomas McLarty]] was under the impression that it would not say anything new or controversial.<ref name = timesfd/> Some human rights campaigners also objected to Clinton speaking in China, fearing it would legitimize that government, and a State Department condition was that Chinese human rights activist [[Harry Wu]] be released before she would appear, which he was.<ref name=timesfd/> Some vocal Catholic groups criticized the gathering as "anti-family" while some ideological conservatives said that Clinton was clearly going to push a "radical feminist agenda" while there.<ref name=timesfd/>
Cecilia Medina was part of the [[United Nations Human Rights Committee]] in 1995 and so may have influenced the speech.{{cn|date=January 2017}}
Once it happened on 5 September 1995, Clinton's speech was delivered in a large hall at the conference.<ref name=timesfd/> In it, she argued against practices abusing women around the world and in China itself.<ref name="nyt090695">{{cite news |last=Tyler |first=Patrick |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/06/world/hillary-clinton-in-china-details-abuse-of-women.html |title=Hillary Clinton, In China, Details Abuse of Women |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 6, 1995}}</ref> Targeting governments and organizations as well as individual females, she stated her belief that the issues facing women and girls are often either ignored or "silenced" and thus go unresolved.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Clinton|first=Hillary Rodham|title=Women's Rights Are Human Rights|journal=[[Women's Studies Quarterly]]|date=1996|volume=24|issue=1/2|pages=98–101|jstor=40004518}}</ref> Elements brought up in the speech include [[dowry death]]s and China's [[one-child policy]].<ref name="nyt090695" />
Clinton declared "that it is no longer acceptable to discuss women's rights as separate from human rights".<ref name="nyt090695" /> Delegates from over 180 countries heard her say:
{{cquote|"If there is one message that echoes forth from this conference, let it be that human rights are women's rights and women's rights are human rights, once and for all."<ref name="nw-doctrine">{{cite news |url=http://www.newsweek.com/2011/03/06/the-hillary-doctrine.html |title=The Hillary Doctrine |last=Lemmon | first=Gayle Tzemach |magazine=[[Newsweek]] |date=March 6, 2011}}</ref>}}
She followed this by saying, "As long as discrimination and inequities remain so commonplace everywhere in the world, as long as girls and women are valued less, fed less, fed last, overworked, underpaid, not schooled, subjected to violence in and outside their homes—the potential of the human family to create a peaceful, prosperous world will not be realized."<ref name=nw-doctrine/> A number of the women delegates at the conference pounded on tables and cheered as she spoke.<ref name=nw-doctrine/>
China's citizenry was not allowed to attend the speech, and it was blacked out on Chinese radio and television.<ref name="nyt090695"/>
The speech received prominent media attention at the time.<ref name=nbcnn>[http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/flashback-first-lady-hillary-clinton-china-n58001 "Flashback: First Lady Hillary Clinton in China"], BETSY FISCHER MARTIN and GRACE LAMB-ATKINSON, NBC News, 20 March 2014</ref> [[NBC News]] anchor [[Tom Brokaw]] said, "In her own way, she made a direct hit on the Chinese," while that network's correspondent [[Andrea Mitchell]] said it was "highly unusual" for a U.S. first lady to engage in this kind of significant diplomatic activity.<ref name=nbcnn /> ''The New York Times'' said that Clinton spoke "more forcefully on human rights than any American dignitary has on Chinese soil."<ref name="nyt090695"/>
== Legacy == The speech is considered to be influential in the women's rights movement. Specifically, it became a key moment in the empowerment of women, and years later women around the world would recite Clinton's key phrases.<ref>{{cite book | title=The Hillary Doctrine: Sex & American Foreign Policy | last=Hudson | first=Valerie M. | last2=Leidl | first2=Patricia | publisher=[[Columbia University Press]] | year=2015 | isbn=0-231-16492-0 | location=New York |pages=7-8|via=}}</ref>
The speech was listed as number 35 in American Rhetoric's Top 100 Speeches of the 20th Century (listed by rank).<ref>{{cite web|author=Michael E. Eidenmuller |url=http://www.americanrhetoric.com/top100speechesall.html |title=Top 100 Speeches of the 20th Century by Rank |publisher=American Rhetoric |date=2009-02-13 |accessdate=2015-10-27}}</ref>
In 2011, Clinton took a similar position on [[LGBT rights by country or territory|LGBT rights]] in a speech to the United Nations on [[International Human Rights Day]], declaring "gay rights are human rights, and human rights are gay rights."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-partisan/post/Clintons-geneva-accord-gay-rights-are-human-rights/2011/03/04/gIQAPUipcO_blog.html|title=Clinton’s Geneva accord: ‘Gay rights are human rights’|last=Capehart|first=Jonathan|date=December 11, 2011|work=[[The Washington Post]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-12}}</ref>
In 2013, following Clinton's stint as [[U.S. Secretary of State]], Clinton led a review at the [[Clinton Global Initiative]] of how women's rights have changed since her 1995 speech.<ref>{{cite news|last=Rucker|first=Philip|title=Hillary Clinton to lead review of progress for women since 1995 Beijing conference|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2013/09/25/hillary-clinton-to-lead-review-of-progress-for-women-since-1995-beijing-conference/|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=September 25, 2013}}</ref> It concluded that progress had been made for girls in education and for women and girls in healthcare but that females around the world still suffered due to lack of political rights and security vulnerabilities.<ref name=timesfd/> In Clinton's words: "It’s a glass-half-filled kind of scenario."<ref name=timesfd/>
On the twentieth anniversary of the speech in 2015 there were more retrospectives on it.<ref name=timesfd >[https://www.nytimes.com/politics/first-draft/2015/09/05/20-years-later-hillary-clintons-beijing-speech-on-women-resonates/?_r=0 "Hillary Clinton' Beijing Speech on Women Resonates 20 Years Later"], Amy Chozick, ''The New York Times'', 5 September 2015</ref> Not everyone was enamored of it: publicly visible lawyer [[Bruce Fein]] said: “She made one statement in Beijing that wasn’t very profound — that women are human beings.”<ref name=timesfd/>
The speech and phrase became a focal point of [[Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2016|Clinton's 2016 presidential campaign]].<ref name=timesfd/> The campaign sold T-shirts stating "women's rights are human rights" at her campaign store, in reference to her speech.<ref>{{cite web|author=Apparel |url=https://shop.hillaryclinton.com/products/the-trailblazer-tee |title=The Trailblazer Tee | Shop | Hillary for America Shop |publisher=Shop.hillaryclinton.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-28}}</ref> The campaign also sold a bag that featured the full phrase "Human rights are women's rights and women's rights are human rights"; on the bag it was shown in six languages.<ref>{{cite web|author=Accessories |url=https://shop.hillaryclinton.com/products/statement-bag |title=Statement Bag | The Shop |publisher=Shop.hillaryclinton.com |date= |accessdate=2015-09-19}}</ref> As well, the campaign sold a [[Tory Burch]] T-shirt featuring the phrase "women's rights are human rights..." in capital letters.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://shop.hillaryclinton.com/products/tory-burch-tee |title=Tory Burch Tee | The Shop |publisher=Shop.hillaryclinton.com |date=2016-06-23 |accessdate=2016-08-06}}</ref> The campaign also created photo references and displays of items necessary for five Halloween costumes, including "'Women’s rights are human rights' Hillary".<ref>{{cite news|last=Singer |first=Paul |url=http://onpolitics.usatoday.com/2015/10/26/hillary-clinton-campaign-sanctions-official-halloween-costume-ideas/ |title=Hillary Clinton campaign sanctions official Halloween costume ideas ||work=[[USA Today]]|date=2015-01-21 |accessdate=2015-10-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hillaryclinton.com/feed/halloween/ |title=Texts from Hillary and 4 other DIY Hillary Clinton costumes for Halloween | The Feed | Hillary for America |publisher=Hillaryclinton.com |date= |accessdate=2015-10-27}}</ref>
In [[Jennifer Lopez]]'s 2016 music video for her song "[[Ain't Your Mama]]", a sample of Clinton giving part of her speech can be heard, specifically, "Human rights are women’s rights, and women’s rights are human rights, once and for all."<ref>Gostin, Nicki [http://m.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/jennifer-lopez-samples-hillary-clinton-speech-new-music-video-article-1.2627353 "Jennifer Lopez samples Hillary Clinton speech in new music video"] ''[[New York Daily News]]'', 6 May 2016<!-- Bot generated title --></ref><ref>[http://www.americanrhetoric.com/speeches/hillaryclintonbeijingspeech.htm "Hillary Rodham Clinton – United Nations 4th World Conference Speech"] American Rhetoric <!-- Bot generated title -->.</ref>
In 2017, for [[International Women's Day]], [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] released a short film titled ''Her-Story''; it ends with the message "Women's rights are human rights."<ref>{{cite web|last=Legaspi |first=Althea |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/see-madonnas-stylish-international-womens-day-short-film-w471211 |title=See Madonna's Stylish International Women's Day Short Film |publisher=Rolling Stone |date=2017-03-08 |accessdate=2017-03-16}}</ref>
As evidenced by physician Leslie Regan in ''[[The Journal of Sexual Medicine]]'', the phrase remains relevant in political discourse in the 2010s, specifically with regards to the discussion of policy regarding women's sexual health and reproductive rights.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Regan|first=Lesley|title=Integrating Human Rights and Women’s Health. Competencies for Practice|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jsxm.2017.04.162|journal=The Journal of Sexual Medicine|volume=14|issue=5|pages=e221–e222|doi=10.1016/j.jsxm.2017.04.162}}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=August 2015}} {{ Infobox Livery Company | name = Worshipful Company of Leathersellers | image = [[File:Leatherseller's Hall, London.jpg|250px]] | motto = ''Soli Deo Honor et Gloria'' | location = The Leathersellers' Co.,
7 St Helen's Place,
London EC3A 6AB | formation = 1444 | association = Leather industries | precedence = 15th | master = Mike Bradly Russell FCA | website = [http://www.leathersellers.co.uk/ www.leathersellers.co.uk] }} The '''Worshipful Company of Leathersellers''' is one of the [[Livery Company|Livery Companies]] of the [[City of London]]. The organisation originates from the latter part of the fourteenth century and received its [[Royal Charter]] in 1444, and thereby is the senior leather industry-related City Livery Company. The Leathersellers' Company ranks fifteenth in the [[order of precedence]] of Livery Companies. The Company's [[motto]] is ''Soli Deo Honor et Gloria'', [[Latin]] for ''Honour and Glory to God Alone''. ==Activities== The Company, which originally regulated [[leather]] [[merchant]]s, continues to act as an advocate for the [[UK]] leather trade, together with its leather-associated livery partners: ''Cordwainers'', ''Curriers'', ''Girdlers'', ''Glovers'' and ''Saddlers'' . Like all these other Companies, today it is primarily involved in philanthropic, charitable and educational activities. ==Schools== The [[Livery Company|Company]] is very closely linked with the Leathersellers' Federation of Schools (formerly Prendergast School), now comprising [[Prendergast Hilly Fields College]], [[Prendergast Ladywell Fields College]] and [[Prendergast Vale College]], all located within the [[London Borough of Lewisham]]. Since the mid-seventeenth century the Company has also been closely associated with [[Colfe's School]], today an independent co-educational school located at Lee, near [[Lewisham]], [[London]]. In addition the Company supports and maintains its longstanding connection with the Institute for Creative Leather Technologies (now a part of the [[University of Northampton]]),[http://www.northampton.ac.uk/info/20521/research-in-the-school-of-science-and-technology/773/institute-for-creative-leather-technologies ''Institute for Creative Leather Technologies''] successor to the college which the Company founded at [[Bermondsey]] in 1909 as Leathersellers' Technical College. The Company continues to support higher education through [[exhibition]]s (grants) to university students, a practice which began in 1603 when four 'poor scholars', two at [[University of Oxford|Oxford]] and two at [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]], were awarded five pounds and five shillings each ''per annum''. Today around 100 students receive exhibitions which enable them to study at various universities. ==Affiliations== The Company is affiliated with the Royal Navy's submarine [[HMS Tireless|HMS ''Tireless'']] and with [[1st The Queen's Dragoon Guards]]. ==Almshouses== Like many other Livery Companies, it has a long tradition of maintaining [[almshouses]]. The first almshouses run by the Company were built circa 1543-44, close to Leathersellers' Hall, on a site behind [[St Ethelburga's Bishopsgate|St Ethelburga's Church]] and housed seven elderly people. In 1837 the Company also built almshouses at [[Chipping Barnet|Barnet]] in north London. These were extended in the mid-nineteenth century. In 1866 it was decided to close the almshouses in the City and remove the residents from there to join those already at Barnet. The Company still maintains almshouses in the [[London Borough of Barnet]], now known as Leathersellers' Close, home to about 20 residents. The Company has had previous six Halls throughout its history, and is now in its seventh Hall, which was officially opened by HRH the Earl of Wessex in May 2017. Its first hall was on [[London Wall]] but in 1543 the Company acquired the former [[Benedictine]] [[Convent]] of St Helen, off [[Bishopsgate]], and the subsequent Halls have all been on that site, now [[St Helen's Bishopsgate|St Helen's Place]]. The fifth Hall was destroyed in May 1941 during the [[London Blitz]]. The sixth Hall was officially opened in 1960 and was demolished in 2011, though the [[façade]] of the building has been saved. The new, seventh Hall, has been designed by Eric Parry [[Royal Academician|RA]][http://www.royalacademy.org.uk/academicians/architects/eric-parry-ra,596,AR.html www.royalacademy.org.uk - Eric Parry]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.leathersellers.co.uk/ The Leathersellers' Company] {{Livery Companies in the City of London}} {{coords|51.5102|-0.0812|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Leathersellers, Worshipful Company of}} [[Category:Livery companies]] [[Category:14th-century establishments in England]] [[Category:Organisations based in London with royal patronage]] [[Category:Corporatism]] [[Category:Companies of medieval England]] [[Category:Charities based in London]]

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}}
'''Yetta Barsh Shachtman''' (1915–1996) was an [[United States|American]] [[socialist]] politician, married to [[Max Shachtman]], a Marxist theorist.
She wrote most of [[Albert Shanker]]'s weekly columns for the ''[[New York Times]]''. At her funeral, [[Saul Bellow]], a classmate, delivered a eulogy.
Yetta did not write most -- or even any -- of Al's weekly ''New York Times'' pieces. He wrote them himself -- typing with two fingers -- except during a stretch in 1975-76 when New York City was on the verge of bankruptcy and the [[United Federation of Teachers]] was on the verge of a strike (and during the strike itself).
==Further reading== [http://www.marxists.org/history/etol/document/1930s/yetta01.htm In Memory of Yetta Barshevsky], by [[Saul Bellow]]
